case_name: Shaheen Motor Service v. Mysore Transport Undertaking

facts.text: Petition No. 109 of 1961 was filed in Original Jurisdiction as a Writ Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of the Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 109 of 1961. Writ Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of the Fundamental Rights. O. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India, B. R. L. Iyengar and K. P. Bhat, for the petitioner.

facts.text: O. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India, B. R. L. Iyengar and K. P. Bhat appeared for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: O. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India, B. R. L. Iyengar and K. P. Bhat, for the petitioner. V. Viswanatha Sastri, R. Gopalakrishnan and M. Sen, for the respondents. 1961. April 12.

facts.text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, R. Gopalakrishnan and M. Sen appeared for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, R. Gopalakrishnan and M. Sen, for the respondents. 1961. April 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.--The petitioner, who is the proprietor of the Shaheen Motor Service,

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on April 12, 1961 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.--The petitioner, who is the proprietor of the Shaheen Motor Service, used to ply a motor bus for hire on the route Archalli to Saravanabelgola in Hassan District in the State of Mysore.

facts.text: The petitioner is the proprietor of the Shaheen Motor Service and used to ply a motor bus for hire on the route Archalli to Saravanabelgola in Hassan District in the State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, who is the proprietor of the Shaheen Motor Service, used to ply a motor bus for hire on the route Archalli to Saravanabelgola in Hassan District in the State of Mysore. A scheme under s. 68-C of the Motor Vehicles Act of 1939 having been published by the Mysore Transport Undertaking,

facts.text: A scheme under section 68-C of the Motor Vehicles Act of 1939 was published by the Mysore Transport Undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: A scheme under s. 68-C of the Motor Vehicles Act of 1939 having been published by the Mysore Transport Undertaking, the petitioner as one of the persons affected thereby filed objections to the scheme before the State Government under s. 68-D 1  of the Act.

facts.text: The petitioner filed objections to the scheme before the State Government under section 68-D of the Act as one of the persons affected.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner as one of the persons affected thereby filed objections to the scheme before the State Government under s. 68-D 1  of the Act. The State Government however after companysidering the objections a,-id hearing the petitioner approved the scheme,

facts.text: The State Government considered the objections and heard the petitioner before approving the scheme subject to a slight modification.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government however after companysidering the objections a,-id hearing the petitioner approved the scheme, subject to a slight modification with which we arc number companycerned. This approval was given on December 22, 1959. In pursuance of this approved scheme the State Transport Undertaking-the 2nd respondent before us--made applications for permits

facts.text: The State Government approved the scheme on December 22, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This approval was given on December 22, 1959. In pursuance of this approved scheme the State Transport Undertaking-the 2nd respondent before us--made applications for permits but before the Regional Transport Authority companyld issue such permits the present petition was filed

facts.text: The State Transport Undertaking, the 2nd respondent, made applications for permits in pursuance of the approved scheme.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this approved scheme the State Transport Undertaking-the 2nd respondent before us--made applications for permits but before the Regional Transport Authority companyld issue such permits the present petition was filed praying, in the first place, for a writ of certiorari to quash the scheme and some companysequential directions,

facts.text: The present petition was filed before the Regional Transport Authority could issue permits to the State Transport Undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: but before the Regional Transport Authority companyld issue such permits the present petition was filed praying, in the first place, for a writ of certiorari to quash the scheme and some companysequential directions, and secondly for a wait of prohibition to the Regional Transport Authority,

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority, Hassan District is the third respondent.

anchor.surface_text: and secondly for a wait of prohibition to the Regional Transport Authority, Hassan District, who is the third respondent before us to refrain from dealing with the applications for permit made by the 2nd respondent unless and until they are duly published and numberice thereof is given to the petitioner

facts.text: The petition prayed for a writ of certiorari to quash the scheme and sequential directions, and a writ of prohibition to the Regional Transport Authority to refrain from dealing with permit applications unless duly published with notice to petitioner regarding compliance with s. 68-F(1) of Chapter IV-A.

anchor.surface_text: and secondly for a wait of prohibition to the Regional Transport Authority, Hassan District, who is the third respondent before us to refrain from dealing with the applications for permit made by the 2nd respondent unless and until they are duly published and numberice thereof is given to the petitioner and he is allowed to make his representation thereon regarding their companypliance or otherwise with the companyditions of s. 68-F 1  of Chapter IV-A.

facts.text: This Court granted leave to amend the writ petition to the second prayer only and directed a rule to issue in respect of the second prayer by order dated March 21, 1961 after hearing counsel for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: After learned companynsel for the petitioner had been heard, this Court by its order dated March 21, 1961, granted leave to the petitioner to amend the writ petition so as to companyfine it to the second prayer only and directed a rule to issue only in respect of this second prayer. The only question with which we are therefore number companycerned is whether a writ should issue prohibiting,

facts.text: The only issue remaining is whether a writ of prohibition should issue to the Regional Transport Authority from dealing with permit applications by the State Transport Undertaking without publication and notice to the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The only question with which we are therefore number companycerned is whether a writ should issue prohibiting, the Regional Transport Authority, Hassan District, from dealing with the applications for permits made by the State Transport Undertaking unless and until they are duly published and numberice thereof is given to the petitioner and he is allowed to make his representations thereon.

facts.text: In Srinivasa Reddy v. The State of Mysore, a question was raised whether s. 57(3) applied to applications under s. 68-F(1), but the court did not decide it as the application breached s. 57(2).

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that in Srinivasa Reddy. Or.3. v. The State of Mysore Ors.  1  a question was raised whether s. 57 3  applied or number to an application made under s. 68- F 1 . The Court companysidered it unnecessary then to go into the matter as on the facts of that case it was found that the application had number been made in the manner provided in Chapter IV and was actually in breach of s. 57 2  of the Act and so numberpermit companyld be issued on such an application.

facts.text: The court in Srinivasa Reddy held that s. 57(2) applies to applications under s. 68-F(1) as it relates to the manner of making the application.

anchor.surface_text: The provision in s. 57 2  which was applicable to applica- tions under s. 68-F is that an application for a permit shall be made number less than six weeks before the date on which it is desired that the permit shall take effect or if the Regional Transport Authority appoints dates for the receipt of such application on such dates. In that case the Court held that this provision in s. 57 2  is in reality a manner of making the  1  1960 2 S. C.R. 130. application and companysequently it applied to applications made under s. 68-F 1 .

facts.text: Srinivasa Reddy case is reported at 1960 2 S.C.R. 130.
The petitioner contended that no permit can be granted to the State Transport Undertaking until applications are published and notice given under s. 57(3) via s. 68-B.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case as regards this prayer is that under the law numberpermit can be granted to the State Transport Undertaking until the applications for permit have been duly published and numberice has been given to the petitioner of those applications. In support of this proposition learned companynsel advanced two arguments-firstly, that s. 57 3  in Chapter IV of the Act, requires such prior publication with numberice of the date before which representations in companynection with the application may be submitted and that in companysequence of s. 68-B of Chapter IV-A the above provisions of s. 57 3  of Chapter IV have to be followed.

facts.text: The petitioner contended that the Regional Transport Authority acts in a quasi-judicial capacity when dealing with permit applications under s. 68-F(1), entitling the petitioner to notice.

anchor.surface_text: The second argument is that the Regional Transport Authority acts in a quasi-judicial capacity when dealing with applications for permits made under s. 68-F and so the petitioner who will be affected by the issue of the permits is entitled to numberice.

facts.text: The court held that the petitioner is not entitled to relief as the contentions are unsound.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that the petitioners companytention that numberpermit can be granted to the State Transport Undertaking until the applications for permit have been duly published and numberices have been given to the petitioner of these applications is unsound Consequently, the petitioner is number entitled to any relief.

anchor.surface_text: This argument, in our opinion, is fallacious. All that s. 68-B pre-supposes is that there are some provisions in Chapter IV which may apply to matters under Chapter IV-A on that assumption it proceeds to say that if on a matter to which provisions of Chapter IV would prima facie apply there is a provision in Chapter IV-A also which appears applicable the provision in Chapter IV-A will prevail to the extent of its inconsistency with the companyresponding provision in Chapter IV.

arguments.claim: s.57(3) inapplicable to s.68-F(1) applications as it governs merits consideration where RTA has discretion, unlike mandatory issuance after scheme approval

anchor.surface_text: As to what provisions in Chapter IV will apply or no s. 68-B says numberhing and provides numberguidance either expres- sly or by implication. To find out whether a particular provision in Chapter IV  number being inconsistent with any provisions in Chap. IV-A  will apply or number to a matter under Chapter IV-A, we have to examine the matter in question and then decide whether it is of such a nature that it attracts that particular provision of Chapter IV. What then is the matter dealt with under s. 68-F 1  with which we are companycerned in the present case?

arguments.claim: RTA function under s.68-F(1) is ministerial: verify approved scheme pursuance and Chapter IV manner compliance; no public input needed post-scheme approval

anchor.surface_text: Section 68-F 1  companyes into operation when a scheme has already been approved by the State Government under s. 68-D 2 . In order that the approved scheme may be implemented the State Transport Undertaking which is to run and operate. the Transport Service under the scheme must have a permit from the Regio- nal Transport Authority. Section 68-F 1  provides that the State Transport Undertaking will have to apply for a permit in pursuance of the approved scheme and  ii  in the manner specified in Chapter IV.

arguments.claim: s.57(2) applies to s.68-F(1) applications as manner of making (timing), unlike s.57(3); per Srinivasa Reddy

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that in Srinivasa Reddy. Or.3. v. The State of Mysore Ors.  1  a question was raised whether s. 57 3  applied or number to an application made under s. 68- F 1 . The Court companysidered it unnecessary then to go into the matter as on the facts of that case it was found that the application had number been made in the manner provided in Chapter IV and was actually in breach of s. 57 2  of the Act and so numberpermit companyld be issued on such an application. The provision in s. 57 2  which was applicable to applica- tions under s. 68-F is that an application for a permit shall be made number less than six weeks before the date on which it is desired that the permit shall take effect or if the Regional Transport Authority appoints dates for the receipt of such application on such dates.

holdings.text: The petitioner's contention that no permit can be granted to the State Transport Undertaking until the applications for permit have been duly published and notices have been given to the petitioner of these applications is unsound. Consequently, the petitioner is not entitled to any relief.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that the petitioners companytention that numberpermit can be granted to the State Transport Undertaking until the applications for permit have been duly published and numberices have been given to the petitioner of these applications is unsound Consequently,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's arguments on applicability of s.57(3) via s.68-B and quasi-judicial nature of RTA function under s.68-F(1) rejected after statutory interpretation and distinction from general permit applications.

holdings.text: s.68-B does not imply that all provisions of Chapter IV apply to matters under Chapter IV-A if no conflict; it only resolves inconsistencies by prioritizing Chapter IV-A.

anchor.surface_text: This argument, in our opinion, is fallacious. All that s. 68-B pre-supposes is that there are some provisions in Chapter IV which may apply to matters under Chapter IV-A on that assumption it proceeds to say that if on a matter to which provisions of Chapter IV would prima facie apply there is a provision in Chapter IV-A also which appears applicable the provision in Chapter IV-A will prevail to the extent of its inconsistency with the companyresponding provision in Chapter IV.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.68-B shows it presupposes possible applicability but provides no affirmative guidance; only prevails in conflicts.

holdings.text: Whether a provision in Chapter IV applies to a matter under Chapter IV-A (absent inconsistency) requires examining if the nature of the matter attracts that provision.

anchor.surface_text: As to what provisions in Chapter IV will apply or number s. 68-B says numberhing and provides numberguidance either expres- sly or by implication. To find out whether a particular provision in Chapter IV  number being inconsistent with any provisions in Chap. IV-A  will apply or number to a matter under Chapter IV-A, we have to examine the matter in question and then decide whether it is of such a nature that it attracts that particular provision of Chapter IV.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68-B silent on applicability; case-by-case examination based on nature of matter needed.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.57(3) have nothing to do with matters dealt with by s.68-F(1) and are not attracted thereto.

anchor.surface_text: It appears clear to us that the provisions of s. 57 3  have numberhing to do with these matters dealt with by s. 68-F 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.57(3) enables public input for discretionary merits decision; s.68-F(1) mandates permit after scheme approval if formalities met, no discretion or lis.

holdings.text: The provision in s.57(2) applies to applications under s.68-F(1) as it relates to the manner of making the application.

anchor.surface_text: In that case the Court held that this provision in s. 57 2  is in reality a manner of making the  1  1960 2 S. C.R. 130. application and companysequently it applied to applications made under s. 68-F 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Srinivasa Reddy, distinguished from s.57(3); timing is procedural manner.

holdings.text: Regional Transport Authority acts wholly in a ministerial capacity while dealing with an application of the State Transport Undertaking under s.68-F(1).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Regional Transport Authority acts wholly in a ministerial capacity while dealing with an application of the State Transport Undertaking under s. 68-F 1 . The fact that on other occasions and in other matters the Regional Transport Authority has quasi-judicial functions to perform cannot make its function under, s. 68-F 1  a quasi- judicial function.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Duty limited to verifying scheme pursuance and Ch.IV manner compliance; no discretion, no lis requiring notice or representations.

holdings.text: When taking action under s.68-F(2), the Regional Transport Authority is not exercising a quasi-judicial function.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberjustification therefore for saving that when taking action under- s. 68-F 2  the regional Transport Authority is exercising a quasi-judicial function.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Actions mechanical to implement approved scheme terms; no lis between parties.

holdings.text: Deciding conditions to attach to permit under s.48(3) does not involve exercising a quasi-judicial function.

anchor.surface_text: In any case, if the Regional Transport Authority has to decide what companyditions to attach to such a permit, it is number possible to say that it is then exercising a quasi-judicial function.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regard to public interest but no lis between undertaking and public.
